page.title: 16Steetley Chapel.
page.content: { All Saints Church,}or{Steetley {Chapel,}was originally built in 1120, probably by{Gley Le Breton}for his own convenience as a private chapel near his house. Although it is only 56feet long it has been called "the most perfect and elaborate specimen of{Norman architecture}to be found anywhere in Europe". Nineteenth century illustrations show the chapel to be in a poor state of repair, prior to its restoration in 1880. Today the chapel has only a small, regular congregation of around 9 or 10, who attend{Holy Communion}on the 1st and 3rd Sundays in the month, or{Evensong on the 2nd, 3rd and 5th Sundays. The chapel is said to be the one on which {Sir Walter Scott}based Copmanhurst in his novel{Ivanhoe.
